plants.name: Hibiscus rosa-sinensis
plants.description: A tropical evergreen shrub known for its large, colorful, trumpet-shaped flowers. It thrives in warm climates and blooms nearly year-round in tropical zones, with peak blooming in summer months.
plants.bloomingSeason: June to September (peak bloom in summer)
plants.location: Tropical and subtropical regions worldwide, including Hawaii, Southeast Asia, and Pacific Islands
plants.funFact: Hibiscus flowers are often used to make herbal teas believed to have health benefits, like lowering blood pressure.

plants.name: Echinacea purpurea
plants.description: A hardy perennial wildflower native to North America, characterized by daisy-like purple petals and a prominent spiky orange center cone. Known for attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
plants.location: Prairies and open woodlands of eastern and central United States
plants.funFact: Echinacea is widely used in herbal remedies believed to boost the immune system.

plants.name: Banksia grandis
plants.description: A large shrub or small tree native to southwestern Australia, notable for its massive cylindrical golden flower spikes that are rich in nectar, attracting birds and mammals.
plants.funFact: Banksia flowers contain hundreds of tiny individual flowers densely packed into a cone-shaped inflorescence.

plants.name: Alstroemeria aurea
plants.description: A vibrant perennial native to South America, producing clusters of lily-like blossoms with unique markings. Popular in bouquets and gardens for its long-lasting flowers.
plants.bloomingSeason: Summer to early autumn (December to April in Southern Hemisphere, corresponds to August in Northern Hemisphere cultivation)
plants.location: Native to Chile and Argentina; cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Alstroemeria blooms can last up to two weeks when cut, making them excellent for floral arrangements.
